added_lines: from unify import bi_unify_lists import sys from policy.builtin.congressbuiltin import append_map as addmap from policy.builtin.congressbuiltin import CongressBuiltinCategoryMap as cbcmap from policy.builtin.congressbuiltin import CongressBuiltinPred as pred from policy.builtin.congressbuiltin import start_builtin_map as initbuiltin self.cbcmap = cbcmap(initbuiltin) elif self.cbcmap.check_if_builtin(pred(lit.table, lit.arguments, len(lit.arguments), 'True')) : cbc = self.cbcmap.return_builtin_pred(lit.tablename()) builtin_code = cbc.code # copy arguments into variables # PLUGGED is an instance of compile.Literal plugged = lit.plug(context.binding) # PLUGGED.arguments is a list of compile.Term num_inputs = cbc.num_inputs # create args for function args = [] if self.cbcmap.get_builtin_category(pred(lit.table, lit.arguments, len(lit.arguments), 'True')) == 'arithmetic': run_inputs = num_inputs - 1 else: run_inputs = num_inputs for i in xrange(0, run_inputs): assert plugged.arguments[i].is_object(), \ ("Builtins must be evaluated only after their " "inputs are ground: {} with num-inputs {}".format( str(plugged), num_inputs)) args.append(plugged.arguments[i].name) # evaluate builtin: must return number, string, or iterable # of numbers/strings result = self.cbcmap.eval_builtin(builtin_code, args) if self.cbcmap.get_builtin_category(pred(lit.table, lit.arguments, len(lit.arguments), 'True')) == 'arithmetic': args.append(result) if isinstance(result, (int, long, float, basestring)): result = [result] # Turn result into normal objects result = [compile.Term.create_from_python(x) for x in result] # adjust binding list unifier = self.new_bi_unifier() undo = bi_unify_lists(result, unifier, lit.arguments[num_inputs-1:], context.binding) if undo is None: self.print_fail(lit, context.binding, context.depth) return False # otherwise, try to finish proof. added_lines: class Semaphore(threading.Semaphore): def __init__(self, name): super(threading.Semaphore, self).__init__() self._name = name def __enter__(self): self.acquire(True) LOG.debug('__enter__ semaphore "%(lock)s"', {'lock': self._name}) def __exit__(self, t, v, tb): self.release() LOG.debug('__exit__ semaphore "%(lock)s"', {'lock': self._name}) sem = Semaphore()

commit_message:
Remove snapshot_id from _volume_snapshot_create()

There is an argument "snapshot_id" in _volume_snapshot_create(), but
the argument is not used in _volume_snapshot_create().
This patch removes it for cleanup.

Change-Id: Ibaad290e149a863c749c74ace3ba702870b8dd1b

commit_message:
Added network troubleshooting steps

- Depends on https://review.openstack.org/121213 I believe
- Uses xi:include to bring in the networking troubleshooting from the ops guide.

Change-Id: I2567213248d50240ecfc422287b06ffa4af4796e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/66/113066/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
Debugging
Finding a Failure in the Path Use ping to quickly find where a failure exists in the network path. In an instance, first see whether you can ping an external host, such as google.com. If you can, then there shouldn't be a network problem at all. If you can't, try pinging the IP address of the compute node where the instance is hosted. If you can ping this IP, then the problem is somewhere between the compute node and that compute node's gateway. If you can't ping the IP address of the compute node, the problem is between the instance and the compute node. This includes the bridge connecting the compute node's main NIC with the vnet NIC of the instance. One last test is to launch a second instance and see whether the two instances can ping each other. If they can, the issue might be related to the firewall on the compute node. path failures troubleshooting detecting path failures
Troubleshooting Open vSwitch Open vSwitch as used in the previous OpenStack Networking Service examples is a full-featured multilayer virtual switch licensed under the open source Apache 2.0 license. Full documentation can be found at the project's website. In practice, given the preceding configuration, the most common issues are being sure that the required bridges (br-int, br-tun, br-ex, etc.) exist and have the proper ports connected to them. Open vSwitch troubleshooting troubleshooting Open vSwitch The Open vSwitch driver should and usually does manage this automatically, but it is useful to know how to do this by hand with the ovs-vsctl command. This command has many more subcommands than we will use here; see the man page or use ovs-vsctl --help for the full listing. To list the bridges on a system, use ovs-vsctl list-br. This example shows a compute node that has an internal bridge and a tunnel bridge. VLAN networks are trunked through the eth1 network interface: # ovs-vsctl list-br br-int br-tun eth1-br Working from the physical interface inwards, we can see the chain of ports and bridges. First, the bridge eth1-br, which contains the physical network interface eth1 and the virtual interface phy-eth1-br: # ovs-vsctl list-ports eth1-br eth1 phy-eth1-br Next, the internal bridge, br-int, contains int-eth1-br, which pairs with phy-eth1-br to connect to the physical network shown in the previous bridge, patch-tun, which is used to connect to the GRE tunnel bridge and the TAP devices that connect to the instances currently running on the system: # ovs-vsctl list-ports br-int int-eth1-br patch-tun tap2d782834-d1 tap690466bc-92 tap8a864970-2d The tunnel bridge, br-tun, contains the patch-int interface and gre-<N> interfaces for each peer it connects to via GRE, one for each compute and network node in your cluster: # ovs-vsctl list-ports br-tun patch-int gre-1 . . . gre-<N> If any of these links is missing or incorrect, it suggests a configuration error. Bridges can be added with ovs-vsctl add-br, and ports can be added to bridges with ovs-vsctl add-port. While running these by hand can be useful debugging, it is imperative that manual changes that you intend to keep be reflected back into your configuration files.
Cannot reach floating IPs If you cannot reach your instances through the floating IP address, check the following: Ensure the default security group allows ICMP (ping) and SSH (port 22), so that you can reach the instances: $ nova secgroup-list-rules default +-------------+-----------+---------+-----------+--------------+ | IP Protocol | From Port | To Port | IP Range | Source Group | +-------------+-----------+---------+-----------+--------------+ | icmp | -1 | -1 | 0.0.0.0/0 | | | tcp | 22 | 22 | 0.0.0.0/0 | | +-------------+-----------+---------+-----------+--------------+

Swine turkey jowl, porchetta doner boudin meatloaf. Shoulder capicola prosciutto, shank landjaeger short ribs sirloin turducken pork belly boudin frankfurter chuck. Salami shankle bresaola cow filet mignon ham hock shank. </para>

commit_message:
Add link to Networking extensions

The sentence was incomplete, finish it and add proper link.
Remove also a broken link.

Change-Id: Iae7616b5ebd327f1ea68302e5e29f4f85f8ec904

commit_message:
Fix parsing sloppiness from iscsiadm discover

As reported by a user, iscsiadm might spew some other random gorp when
it starts up, and if it does, nova explodes poorly. Put a modicum of
sanity testing into the parsing of the output to make this less
likely.

Change-Id: Iaf55438bb3ec412187158e80f9fbc1d8e7071207
Closes-Bug: #1308649
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/120958/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # as we are parsing a command line utility, allow for the # possibility that additional debug data is spewed in the # stream, and only grab actual ip / iqn lines. targets = [] for data in [line.split() for line in output.splitlines()]: if len(data) == 2 and data[1].startswith('iqn.'): targets.append(data) return targets

commit_message:
Use integer instead of string for form max_length

This is a follow-up patch of a comment
in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/119134/

Change-Id: I87f0a5698e5ccde251eb9cd9c1280291f5d746e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/11/119811/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: max_length=255,

subject: Add reset-state function for backups
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-26 10:41:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/f743b00f13ee4ca7ed6a2ff60d2d1a8ee0a7b9ba', 'message': 'Add reset-state function for backups

Since there are volume reset-state function and snapshot reset-state
function,
backup also needs reset-state as well.
When creating or restoring backup, it may leave the backup stucked in
creating
or restoring status due to database down or rabbitmq down, etc.
Currently we could only solve these problems by restarting cinder-backup
service.
This BP is to provide another mean for administrators to solve these
problems by
calling backup reset state API, instead of directly restarting
cinder-backup service.

blueprint Add reset-state function for backups

Change-Id: Icd677a0b48083894bcd969d5199fa91b307080de
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-08-26 10:42:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/3f2875e995de82a96629868b17e51344960d7bfd', 'message': 'Add reset-state function for backups

function, backup also needs reset-state as well.
When creating or restoring backup, it may leave the backup stucked in
creating or restoring status due to database down or rabbitmq down, etc.
Currently we could only solve these problems by restarting cinder-backup
service.

This BP is to provide another mean for administrators to solve these
problems by calling backup reset state API, instead of directly restarting
cinder-backup service.

blueprint Add reset-state function for backups

Change-Id: Icd677a0b48083894bcd969d5199fa91b307080de

commit_message:
Add reset-state function for backups

Since there are volume reset-state function and snapshot reset-state
function, backup also needs reset-state as well.
When creating or restoring backup, it may leave the backup stuck in
creating or restoring status due to database down or rabbitmq down, etc.
Currently we could only solve these problems by restarting cinder-backup
service.

This BP is to provide another means for administrators to solve these
problems by calling backup reset state API, instead of directly
restarting cinder-backup service.

DocImpact: Support reset backup status

blueprint support-reset-state-for-backup

Change-Id: Icd677a0b48083894bcd969d5199fa91b307080de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/49/116849/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mockfrom cinder.backup import driver def _issue_backup_reset(self, ctx, backup, updated_status): req = webob.Request.blank('/v2/fake/backups/%s/action' % backup['id']) req.method = 'POST' req.headers['content-type'] = 'application/json' req.body = \ jsonutils.dumps({'os-reset_status': updated_status}) req.environ['cinder.context'] = ctx resp = req.get_response(app()) return resp def test_backup_reset_status_as_admin(self): ctx = context.RequestContext('admin', 'fake', True) volume = db.volume_create(ctx, {'status': 'available'}) backup = db.backup_create(ctx, {'status': 'available', 'size': 1, 'volume_id': volume['id']}) resp = self._issue_backup_reset(ctx, backup, {'status': 'error'}) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) backup = db.backup_get(ctx, backup['id']) self.assertEqual(backup['status'], 'error') def test_backup_reset_status_as_non_admin(self): ctx = context.RequestContext('fake', 'fake') volume = db.volume_create(ctx, {'status': 'available'}) backup = db.backup_create(ctx, {'status': 'available', 'size': 1, 'volume_id': volume['id']}) resp = self._issue_backup_reset(ctx, backup, {'status': 'error'}) # request is not authorized self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 403) backup = db.backup_get(context.get_admin_context(), backup['id']) # status is still 'available' self.assertEqual(backup['status'], 'available') def test_backup_reset_status_creating_to_available_ok(self): ctx = context.RequestContext('admin', 'fake', True) volume = db.volume_create(ctx, {'status': 'available', 'host': 'test', 'provider_location': '', 'size': 1}) backup = db.backup_create(ctx, {'status': 'error', 'volume_id': volume['id']}) with mock.patch.object(driver.BackupDriver, 'verify') as \ mock_verify: mock_verify.return_value = True resp = self._issue_backup_reset(ctx, backup, {'status': 'available'}) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) backup = db.backup_get(ctx, backup['id']) self.assertEqual(backup['status'], 'available') def test_backup_reset_status_creating_to_available_no_ok(self): ctx = context.RequestContext('admin', 'fake', True) volume = db.volume_create(ctx, {'status': 'available', 'host': 'test', 'provider_location': '', 'size': 1}) backup = db.backup_create(ctx, {'status': 'creating', 'volume_id': volume['id']}) with mock.patch.object(driver.BackupDriver, 'verify') as \ mock_verify: mock_verify.return_value = False resp = self._issue_backup_reset(ctx, backup, {'status': 'available'}) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) backup = db.backup_get(ctx, backup['id']) self.assertEqual(backup['status'], 'creating') def test_backup_reset_status_creating_to_available_not_implement(self): ctx = context.RequestContext('admin', 'fake', True) volume = db.volume_create(ctx, {'status': 'available', 'host': 'test', 'provider_location': '', 'size': 1}) backup = db.backup_create(ctx, {'status': 'creating', 'volume_id': volume['id']}) with mock.patch.object(driver.BackupDriver, 'verify') as \ mock_verify: mock_verify.side_effect = NotImplementedError resp = self._issue_backup_reset(ctx, backup, {'status': 'available'}) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) backup = db.backup_get(ctx, backup['id']) self.assertEqual(backup['status'], 'creating') def test_backup_reset_status_to_error(self): ctx = context.RequestContext('admin', 'fake', True) volume = db.volume_create(ctx, {'status': 'available', 'host': 'test', 'provider_location': '', 'size': 1}) backup = db.backup_create(ctx, {'status': 'creating', 'volume_id': volume['id']}) print('[2014-08-26] backup id 0: %s', backup['id']) print('[2014-08-26] backup status 0: %s', backup['status']) resp = self._issue_backup_reset(ctx, backup, {'status': 'error'}) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) backup = db.backup_get(ctx, backup['id']) print('[2014-08-26] backup id: %s', backup['id']) print('[2014-08-26] backup status: %s', backup['status']) self.assertEqual(backup['status'], 'error') def test_backup_reset_status_restoring_to_available(self): ctx = context.RequestContext('admin', 'fake', True) volume = db.volume_create(ctx, {'status': 'available', 'host': 'test', 'provider_location': '', 'size': 1}) backup = db.backup_create(ctx, {'status': 'restoring', 'volume_id': volume['id']}) resp = self._issue_backup_reset(ctx, backup, {'status': 'available'}) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) backup = db.backup_get(ctx, backup['id']) self.assertEqual(backup['status'], 'available')

commit_message:
Fix message informing of missing username or password

Fix message displayed when client is executed without required
environment variables exported (OS_USERNAME, OS_PASSWORD,
OS_PROJECT_NAME, OS_AUTH_URL). Also add regression tests.

Change-Id: Ic482934a1549784b391696ddc39562fce8df6627
Closes-Bug: 1355252

added_lines: @mock.patch('glanceclient.v1.client.Client') def test_auth_plugin_invocation_without_username(self, v1_client): del os.environ['OS_USERNAME'] args = 'image-list' glance_shell = openstack_shell.OpenStackImagesShell() self.assertRaises(exc.CommandError, glance_shell.main, args.split()) @mock.patch('glanceclient.v1.client.Client') def test_auth_plugin_invocation_without_password(self, v1_client): del os.environ['OS_PASSWORD'] args = 'image-list' glance_shell = openstack_shell.OpenStackImagesShell() self.assertRaises(exc.CommandError, glance_shell.main, args.split())

commit_message:

hostname_to_ip to convert hostnames to IP addresses.

commit_message:
labs: move network-api IP address

Eth3 is used for a bridge and should therefore not have an IP address.
With the network-api address remaining on eth3, we can't talk to
controller-api.

This patch moves the IP address to the switch-internal network device
of the bridge, br-ex.

Change-Id: I2a52844a160fe7ccd95e8d1aa16eb2d451dd605f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/68/120368/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: network_api_ip=$(hostname_to_ip network-api) echo "Moving network-api IP address from eth3 to a switch-internal device." sudo ifconfig eth3 0.0.0.0 sudo ifconfig br-ex "$network_api_ip" echo "Making the IP address move reboot-safe." sudo sed -i "s/$network_api_ip/0.0.0.0/" /etc/network/interfaces cat << INTERFACES | sudo tee -a /etc/network/interfaces auto br-ex iface br-ex inet static address $network_api_ip netmask 255.255.255.0 INTERFACES # Check if we can get to the API network again ping -c 1 controller-api

labs: fix metadata_agent authentication

The config file, metadata_agent.ini, uses auth_url (not auth_uri).

Change-Id: Id14a2ac2d2ad70fe2a354e47913566b7ea9c37b2

commit_message:
VMware: Enable vCenter SSL certificate validation

During https/ssl communication the server certificate of
a vCenter is not validated during https handshake process.
This patch will enable the certificate validation against root
certificate of the vCenter to validate the identity of that vCenter.
Nova, Cinder etc will need to specify the cacert parameter
for this to take effect.

Ported from Id: Ic24951630698068321bb62d3098de8344a35c5d0

Closes-Bug: #1276207
Co-Authored-By: Johnson koil raj <johnson.raj@hp.com>
Change-Id: I422e6d4df4e392334c0ce47e6f5b017a8c95f61a

commit_message:
Fix AttributeError in VolumeSnapshot

This fixes a regression introduced in
Hiding "Launch as Instance" if volume is not bootable.

Change-Id: I9c45a1f5f4e3a096843ba6547dbf76387501f447
Closes-Bug: 1368732

subject: VMware: Remove redundant extend disk API call
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-20 14:23:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/707543be570279fdcd06d1d87d017d86e01763ee', 'message': 'VMware: Remove redundant extend disk API call

Extend virtual disk API is called during volume creation from image if
the image size is less than volume size. In the case of streamOptimized
and sparse vmdk images, the size of the virtual disk created from the
image can be greater than image size and equal to the volume size. For
example, streamOptimized image created from a new 1GB volume has size
69120 bytes and the size of the virtual disk created from this image
is 1GB. Therefore, relying on image size to invoke extend API might
result in VIM API fault, if the virtual disk size is same as the target
size (volume size). The fix is to read the current virtual disk size to
decide whether extend disk needs to be invoked or not.

Closes-Bug: #1301854
Change-Id: I990ac0b9aef68b3ef8b6d67188db8d44b5c29599
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-08-20 14:26:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/4bef1e5d8105db0b2016d42f19626d3835fc94cc', 'message': 'VMware: Remove redundant extend disk API call

decide whether extend disk needs to be invoked or not.

Change-Id: I990ac0b9aef68b3ef8b6d67188db8d44b5c29599

commit_message:
VMware: Remove redundant extend disk API call

Extend virtual disk API is called during volume creation from image if
the image size is less than volume size. In the case of streamOptimized
and sparse vmdk images, the size of the virtual disk created from the
image can be greater than image size and equal to the volume size. For
example, streamOptimized image created from a new 1GB volume has size
69120 bytes and the size of the virtual disk created from this image
is 1GB. Therefore, relying on image size to invoke extend API might
result in VIM API fault, if the virtual disk size is same as the target
size (volume size). The fix is to read the current virtual disk size to
decide whether extend disk needs to be invoked or not.

Closes-Bug: #1301854
Change-Id: I990ac0b9aef68b3ef8b6d67188db8d44b5c29599
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/58/115658/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: vops, select_ds_for_volume, generate_uuid): generate_uuid) vops, select_ds_for_volume, generate_uuid): 'size': image_size_in_bytes} # If the volume size is greater then than the image size, _extend_virtual_disk.assert_called_with(fake_volume['name'], fake_volume_size) self.assertFalse(volumeops.get_backing.called) self.assertFalse(volumeops.delete_backing.called) # If the volume size is not greater then than the image size, fake_volume_size = size_gb fake_volume['size'] = fake_volume_size self.assertFalse(volumeops.get_backing.called) self.assertFalse(volumeops.delete_backing.called) vops, select_ds_for_volume, generate_uuid): generate_uuid)

commit_message:
Destroy Datera export target after detach

Since there is only one lun associated with each target export object in
the Datera backend, we will destroy the target export object after
detaching the volume so they don't build up. This patch also fixes some
missing values for formatted strings.

Closes-Bug: #1368381
Change-Id: Id44ac4bb385ab39af50865a295938861ca977fa3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/02/120902/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_detach_volume_success(self): self.mock_api.return_value = {} ctxt = context.get_admin_context() volume = _stub_volume(status='in-use') self.assertIsNone(self.driver.detach_volume(ctxt, volume)) def test_detach_volume_fails(self): self.mock_api.side_effect = exception.DateraAPIException ctxt = context.get_admin_context() volume = _stub_volume(status='in-use') self.assertRaises(exception.DateraAPIException, self.driver.detach_volume, ctxt, volume) def test_detach_volume_not_found(self): self.mock_api.side_effect = exception.NotFound ctxt = context.get_admin_context() volume = _stub_volume(status='in-use') self.assertIsNone(self.driver.detach_volume(ctxt, volume))

subject: libvirt: Consider numa_topology when booting
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-19 19:20:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a670d58815b6bb9ef0b35b4a5e62db10d7050195', 'message': 'libvirt: Consider numa_topology when booting

This patch hooks all the already introduced pieces together to enable
NUMA aware placement of instances.

The libvirt driver boot process now looks into the NUMA topology field
of both instance and the host it is being booted on, and based on that
adds some more configuration to the generated guest XML.

In case the host is NUMA capable, but the instance has not requested
a NUMA topology, we will try to pack the instance into a single cell.
If that fails, currently we will not make further attempts (although
an improvement could be to expose the underlying topology to the
instance).

In case the host is NUMA capable, and instance has requested a specific
NUMA topology, we will try to pin the vCPUs of different instance NUMA
cells to the corresponding host NUMA cells, and also expose the instance
NUMA topology to the guest OS.

We will still try to respect CONF.vcpu_pin_set option and avoid pinning
to CPUs that are not in this set.

Change-Id: I611d44ab75475028f63c2b7f8a0d2ef37d85be6e
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement

This patch hooks all the already introduced pieces together to enable
NUMA aware placement of instances.

The libvirt driver boot process now looks into the NUMA topology field
of both instance and the host it is being booted on, and based on that
adds some more configuration to the generated guest XML.

In case the host is NUMA capable, but the instance has not requested
a NUMA topology, we will try to pack the instance into a single cell.
If that fails, currently we will not make further attempts (although
an improvement could be to expose the underlying topology to the
instance).

In case the host is NUMA capable, and instance has requested a specific
NUMA topology, we will try to pin the vCPUs of different instance NUMA
cells to the corresponding host NUMA cells, and also expose the instance
NUMA topology to the guest OS.

We will still try to respect CONF.vcpu_pin_set option and avoid pinning
to CPUs that are not in this set.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I611d44ab75475028f63c2b7f8a0d2ef37d85be6e
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement

We will still try to respect CONF.vcpu_pin_set option and avoid pinning

commit_message:
libvirt: Consider numa_topology when booting

This patch hooks all the already introduced pieces together to enable
NUMA aware placement of instances.

The libvirt driver boot process now looks into the NUMA topology field
of both instance and the host it is being booted on, and based on that
adds some more configuration to the generated guest XML.

In case the host is NUMA capable, but the instance has not requested
a NUMA topology, we will try to pack the instance into a single cell.
If that fails, currently we will not make further attempts (although
an improvement could be to expose the underlying topology to the
instance).

In case the host is NUMA capable, and instance has requested a specific
NUMA topology, we will try to pin the vCPUs of different instance NUMA
cells to the corresponding host NUMA cells, and also expose the instance
NUMA topology to the guest OS.

We will still try to respect CONF.vcpu_pin_set option and avoid pinning
to CPUs that are not in this set.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I611d44ab75475028f63c2b7f8a0d2ef37d85be6e
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/115381/28 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('random.randint', return_value=0) def test_get_guest_config_numa_host_instance_fits(self, randint_mock): instance_ref = db.instance_create(self.context, self.test_instance) flavor = objects.Flavor(memory_mb=1, vcpus=2, root_gb=496, ephemeral_gb=8128, swap=33550336, name='fake', extra_specs={}) caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.cpu = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCPU() caps.host.cpu.arch = "x86_64" caps.host.topology = self._fake_caps_numa_topology() conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) disk_info = blockinfo.get_disk_info(CONF.libvirt.virt_type, instance_ref) with contextlib.nested( mock.patch.object( objects.Flavor, "get_by_id", return_value=flavor), mock.patch.object( conn, "_get_host_capabilities", return_value=caps)): cfg = conn._get_guest_config(instance_ref, [], {}, disk_info) self.assertEqual(set([0, 1]), cfg.cpuset) self.assertIsNone(cfg.cputune) self.assertIsNone(cfg.cpu.numa) @mock.patch('random.randint', return_value=0) def test_get_guest_config_numa_host_instance_no_fit(self, randint_mock): instance_ref = db.instance_create(self.context, self.test_instance) flavor = objects.Flavor(memory_mb=1, vcpus=4, root_gb=496, ephemeral_gb=8128, swap=33550336, name='fake', extra_specs={}) caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.cpu = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCPU() caps.host.cpu.arch = "x86_64" caps.host.topology = self._fake_caps_numa_topology() conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) disk_info = blockinfo.get_disk_info(CONF.libvirt.virt_type, instance_ref) with contextlib.nested( mock.patch.object( objects.Flavor, "get_by_id", return_value=flavor), mock.patch.object( conn, "_get_host_capabilities", return_value=caps), mock.patch.object( hardware, 'get_vcpu_pin_set', return_value=set([3]))): cfg = conn._get_guest_config(instance_ref, [], {}, disk_info) self.assertEqual(set([3]), cfg.cpuset) self.assertIsNone(cfg.cputune) self.assertIsNone(cfg.cpu.numa) def test_get_guest_config_non_numa_host_instance_topo(self): instance_topology = hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCell(1, set([0]), 1024), hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCell(2, set([2]), 1024)]) self.test_instance['numa_topology'] = instance_topology.to_json() instance_ref = db.instance_create(self.context, self.test_instance) flavor = objects.Flavor(memory_mb=1, vcpus=2, root_gb=496, ephemeral_gb=8128, swap=33550336, name='fake', extra_specs={}) caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.cpu = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCPU() caps.host.cpu.arch = "x86_64" caps.host.topology = None conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) disk_info = blockinfo.get_disk_info(CONF.libvirt.virt_type, instance_ref) with contextlib.nested( mock.patch.object( objects.Flavor, "get_by_id", return_value=flavor), mock.patch.object( conn, "_get_host_capabilities", return_value=caps)): cfg = conn._get_guest_config(instance_ref, [], {}, disk_info) self.assertIsNone(cfg.cpuset) self.assertIsNone(cfg.cputune) self.assertIsNotNone(cfg.cpu.numa) for instance_cell, numa_cfg_cell in zip( instance_topology.cells, cfg.cpu.numa.cells): self.assertEqual(instance_cell.id, numa_cfg_cell.id) self.assertEqual(instance_cell.cpuset, numa_cfg_cell.cpus) self.assertEqual(instance_cell.memory, numa_cfg_cell.memory) def test_get_guest_config_numa_host_instance_topo(self): instance_topology = hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCell(1, set([0]), 1024), hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCell(2, set([1]), 1024)]) self.test_instance['numa_topology'] = instance_topology.to_json() instance_ref = db.instance_create(self.context, self.test_instance) flavor = objects.Flavor(memory_mb=1, vcpus=2, root_gb=496, ephemeral_gb=8128, swap=33550336, name='fake', extra_specs={}) caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.cpu = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCPU() caps.host.cpu.arch = "x86_64" caps.host.topology = self._fake_caps_numa_topology() conn = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) disk_info = blockinfo.get_disk_info(CONF.libvirt.virt_type, instance_ref) with contextlib.nested( mock.patch.object( objects.Flavor, "get_by_id", return_value=flavor), mock.patch.object( conn, "_get_host_capabilities", return_value=caps), mock.patch.object( hardware, 'get_vcpu_pin_set', return_value=set([0, 1, 2])) ): cfg = conn._get_guest_config(instance_ref, [], {}, disk_info) self.assertIsNone(cfg.cpuset) # Test that the pinning is correct and limited to allowed only self.assertEqual(0, cfg.cputune.vcpupin[0].id) self.assertEqual(set([0, 1]), cfg.cputune.vcpupin[0].cpuset) self.assertEqual(1, cfg.cputune.vcpupin[1].id) self.assertEqual(set([2]), cfg.cputune.vcpupin[1].cpuset) self.assertIsNotNone(cfg.cpu.numa) for instance_cell, numa_cfg_cell in zip( instance_topology.cells, cfg.cpu.numa.cells): self.assertEqual(instance_cell.id, numa_cfg_cell.id) self.assertEqual(instance_cell.cpuset, numa_cfg_cell.cpus) self.assertEqual(instance_cell.memory, numa_cfg_cell.memory) def _fake_caps_numa_topology(self): topology = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsNUMATopology() cell_0.memory = 1024 cell_1.memory = 1024 topology.cells = [cell_0, cell_1] return topology def test_get_host_numa_topology(self): caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.topology = self._fake_caps_numa_topology() 'mem': {'total': 1024, 'used': 0}, 'mem': {'total': 1024, 'used': 0},

subject: Add the NUMATopologyFilter
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-18 16:04:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5ff0ea61dd29df74bcc9cf3c20c4f212b5e85a2f', 'message': 'Add the NUMATopologyFilter

This patch adds the basic NUMA filter that will take the proposed
instance topology and try to match it against that of a host.

The matching will be done in the following manner:

 * Filter will try to match the exact cells of the instance to those of
   the host. It *will not* attempt to pack the instance onto the host.
 * It will consider the standard over-subscription limits for each cell,
   and provide limits to the compute host accordingly.
 * In case instance has no topology defined, it will be considered for
   any host.
 * In case the host is not a NUMA host - it will be considered by this
   filter always

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8788dde69524c8a32a41ce31a96c89f9b09e91ce
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement

'}, {'number': 24, 'created': '2014-09-08 14:41:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5913a2d9d3fffaa29e8ff6c177750cc5bc1efc14', 'message': 'Add the NUMATopologyFilter

This patch adds the basic NUMA filter that will take the proposed
instance topology and try to match it against that of a host.

The matching will be done in the following manner:

 * Filter will try to match the exact cells of the instance to those of
   the host. It *will not* attempt to pack the instance onto the host.
 * It will consider the standard over-subscription limits for each cell,
   and provide limits to the compute host accordingly.
 * In case instance has no topology defined, it will be considered for
   any host.
 * In case instance has a topology defined, it will be considered only
   for NUMA capable hosts.
 * In case the host is not a NUMA host - it will be considered by this
   filter always

DocImpact

This patch adds the basic NUMA filter that will take the proposed
instance topology and try to match it against that of a host.

The matching will be done in the following manner:

 * Filter will try to match the exact cells of the instance to those of
   the host. It *will not* attempt to pack the instance onto the host.
 * It will consider the standard over-subscription limits for each cell,
   and provide limits to the compute host accordingly.
 * In case instance has no topology defined, it will be considered for
   any host.
 * In case instance has a topology defined, it will be considered only
   for NUMA capable hosts.
 * In case the host is not a NUMA host - it will be considered by this
   filter always

commit_message:
Add the NUMATopologyFilter

This patch adds the basic NUMA filter that will take the proposed
instance topology and try to match it against that of a host.

The matching will be done in the following manner:

 * Filter will try to match the exact NUMA cells of the instance to those
   of the host. It *will not* attempt to pack the instance onto the host.
 * It will consider the standard over-subscription limits for each cell,
   and provide limits to the compute host accordingly.
 * If instance has no topology defined, it will be considered for any host.
 * If instance has a topology defined, it will be considered only for NUMA
   capable hosts.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8788dde69524c8a32a41ce31a96c89f9b09e91ce
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/115007/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo.config import cfg from nova.openstack.common import log as logging from nova.scheduler import filters from nova.virt import hardware CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.import_opt('cpu_allocation_ratio', 'nova.scheduler.filters.core_filter') CONF.import_opt('ram_allocation_ratio', 'nova.scheduler.filters.ram_filter') LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class NUMATopologyFilter(filters.BaseHostFilter): """Filter on requested NUMA topology.""" def host_passes(self, host_state, filter_properties): ram_ratio = CONF.ram_allocation_ratio cpu_ratio = CONF.cpu_allocation_ratio instance = filter_properties.get('instance_properties', {}) usage_after_instance = hardware.get_host_numa_usage_from_intance( host_state, instance, never_serialize_result=True) limit_cells = [] if usage_after_instance: for cell in usage_after_instance.cells: max_cell_memory = int(cell.memory * ram_ratio) max_cell_cpu = len(cell.cpuset) * cpu_ratio if (cell.memory_usage > max_cell_memory or cell.cpu_usage > max_cell_cpu): return False limit_cells.append( hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCellLimit( cell.id, cell.cpuset, cell.memory, max_cell_cpu, max_cell_memory)) host_state.limits['numa_topology'] = ( hardware.VirtNUMALimitTopology(cells=limit_cells)) return True return True

subject: Make HostManager track NUMA usage

This patch adds tracking of NUMA usage in scheduler's HostManager class,
by adding it to the HostState, and making sure it gets updated along
with all the other usage data.

We also make sure that we can extract NUMA usage from an instance that
is set as part of the request_specs dictionary (which sadly uses
objects_base.obj_to_primitive for stuff that get sent over the wire
which means they lose all the versioning information).

commit_message:
Make HostManager track NUMA usage

This patch adds tracking of NUMA usage in scheduler's HostManager class,
by adding it to the HostState, and making sure it gets updated along
with all the other usage data.

Change-Id: Id31c9a7fd54b918b3d38abb61b305cf7048a6a7d
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement

commit_message:
Sync with latest oslo-incubator

Last commit: 32e7f0b56f527427544050f251999f3de588ac93

This patch syncs the python-keystoneclient with olso-incubator as I
need this patch 4ef01931 which fixes a bug that's I am hitting in
another client which uses the keystoneclient.

commit_message:
Add to configure bind_ip on the storage nodes

The bind_ip under [DEFAULT] section of account-server.conf,
container-server.conf,object-server.conf files under /etc/swift of the
storage nodes need to be changed to the STORAGE_LOCAL_NET_IP.

Change-Id: Icfb92294466d5f38ae5abc80e2e6165802aec58f
Closes-Bug: #1364268
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/43/121343/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Set the bind_ip configuration option to <replaceable>STORAGE_LOCAL_NET_IP</replaceable>.</para> <para os="ubuntu;debian;opensuse;sles">Edit account-server.conf,container-server.conf and object-server.conf in /etc/swift directory and edit the [DEFAULT] section of each file:<programlisting language="ini">[DEFAULT] bind_ip = <replaceable>STORAGE_LOCAL_NET_IP</replaceable> ...</programlisting> </para> <screen os="rhel;centos;fedora"> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>openstack-config --set /etc/swift/account-server.conf DEFAULT bind_ip <replaceable>STORAGE_LOCAL_NET_IP</replaceable></userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>openstack-config --set /etc/swift/container-server.conf DEFAULT bind_ip <replaceable>STORAGE_LOCAL_NET_IP</replaceable></userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>openstack-config --set /etc/swift/object-server.conf DEFAULT bind_ip <replaceable>STORAGE_LOCAL_NET_IP</replaceable></userinput></screen> </step> <step> <para>Make sure the swift user owns all configuration files:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>chown -R swift:swift /etc/swift</userinput></screen> </step> <step>

commit_message:
UTs: Disable auto deletion of ports/subnets/nets

Change the behavior of the unit test context managers
for ports, networks, and subnets to skip the deletion
of the objects they create.

Adds explicit delete calls to the tests that require
deletion of the objects.

This is the first patch in a series to eliminate the
automatic deletion of objects created during tests to
improve test performance and make testing more explicit.

Implements: blueprint remove-unit-test-autodeletion
Change-Id: Ifc4490b121310ad64e18936e6fd94a2c9a1e36f2

commit_message:
Make block devices mounts permanent within service instances

Restart of service VM does not save mount state of block device for share.
So, if we do not restart m-shr we have export to dir that links not to
block device, but to root filesystem of service VM.

Changes:
- added sync method of temp and permanent fs mount files;
- changed lock value for mount operations from share id to service instance id,
  because any action changes common config file;
- updated related unittests;

Change-Id: I874d84f5342208906379aba5572540a984f79f03
Closes-Bug: #1367731

added_lines: def _sync_mount_temp_and_perm_files(self, server_details): """Sync temporary and permanent files for mounter filesystems.""" sync_cmd = [ 'sudo', 'cp ', const.MOUNT_FILE_TEMP, const.MOUNT_FILE, '&&', 'sudo', 'mount', '-a', ] self._ssh_exec(server_details, sync_cmd) @utils.synchronized('generic_driver_mounts_' '%s' % server_details['instance_id']) # Add mount permanently self._sync_mount_temp_and_perm_files(server_details) @utils.synchronized('generic_driver_mounts_' '%s' % server_details['instance_id']) # Remove mount permanently self._sync_mount_temp_and_perm_files(server_details)

added_lines:
args = [os_command] if extra_params: args.extend(extra_params) args.append("bash-completion") all_options = check_output(args).strip().split() if os_command == 'cinder': out_file.write(""" <section xml:id="cinder_cli_v1"> <title>Block Storage API v1 commands</title>
""") if os_command == 'cinder': out_file.write(" </section>
") out_file.write(""" <section xml:id="cinder_cli_v2"> <title>Block Storage API v2 commands</title> <para> You can select an API version to use by adding the <parameter>--os-volume-api-version</parameter> option or by setting the corresponding environment variable:
""") out_file.write("<screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>" "export OS_VOLUME_API_VERSION=2</userinput></screen>
" "</para>
") generate_subcommands(os_command, out_file, blacklist, subcommands, ["--os-volume-api-version", "2"], "_v2", " (v2)") out_file.write(" </section>
")

commit_message:
API boot process sets NUMA topology for instances

This patch makes the API instance boot path look at the bits that can
contain requested topology, generate the desired topology and make sure
it is saved on the instance itself.

We also need to account for the flavor passed to
VirtNUMAInstanceTopology.get_constraints not being an actual Flavor
object, and work with db layer objects.

Change-Id: Ia3f3446da99a04e2d8152acb7d0bda7a1d502c83
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/114483/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except (exception.ImageNUMATopologyIncomplete, exception.ImageNUMATopologyForbidden, exception.ImageNUMATopologyAsymmetric, exception.ImageNUMATopologyCPUOutOfRange, exception.ImageNUMATopologyCPUDuplicates, exception.ImageNUMATopologyCPUsUnassigned, exception.ImageNUMATopologyMemoryOutOfRange) as error: raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=error.format_message())

commit_message:
Remove redirect for trunk Install Guide pages

For the work-in-progress trunk Install Guide, we should not add
redirects, we've marked this properly as Draft, so don't need to
maintain them.

Change-Id: I7dcdcac382bcf2df5da4aa16f97f1f209fbc401a

commit_message:
Increase share-network default quota

Now Manila has too small quota for share networks, that affects gate tests with
exception "ShareNetworksLimitExceeded".

Changes:
- increased quota from 5 to 10;
- updated description of quota with proper info.

Change-Id: I1e3127780785ec689d02a4a0bcce42d903df7d72
Closes-Bug: #1368460
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/67/121167/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default=10, help='Number of share-networks allowed per project.'),
deleted_lines: default=5, help='Number of activated share-networks allowed per project.'),

commit_message:
Provides LBaaS v1.0 extension info

 - removes experimental v2.0
 - Updates health_monitor JSON example

Closes-bug:1214353
Closes-bug:1361413
Change-Id: Id5bd7417090ec65fb6f797870b909c75ba14d634

subject: Fix scheduler-hints example
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-09 18:54:07.000000000', 'files': ['api-ref/src/wadls/compute-api/src/v2/api_samples/OS-SCH-HNT/scheduler-hints-post-req.xml', 'api-ref/src/wadls/compute-api/src/v2/api_samples/OS-SCH-HNT/scheduler-hints-post-req.json'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-site/commit/28a8c944c8116a1c621296cfbb94d3e90743911e', 'message': 'Fix scheduler-hints example

The API samples of scheduler-hints contains "hypervisor" and "near"
attributes, but the attributes do not exist in the scheduler-hints
parameter of "create a server" API. This patch changes them to the
existing "same_host" attribute.

Change-Id: Ia6b34fe5b0327b4499df0e0dac623eb42fb07285
Closes-Bug: #1285456
'}]
commit_message:
Fix scheduler-hints example

The API samples of scheduler-hints contains "hypervisor" and "near"
attributes, but the attributes do not exist in the scheduler-hints
parameter of "create a server" API. This patch changes them to the
existing "same_host" attribute.

Change-Id: Ia6b34fe5b0327b4499df0e0dac623eb42fb07285
Closes-Bug: #1285456
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/82/120182/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "same_host": "2b7c42eb-7736-4a0f-afab-f23969a35ada" } }

commit_message:
Hunormous file rename for v3 to v2.1 for Compute

Nova team decided to do a minor version to 2.1
rather than move to v3 so the API docs need to
reflect that. Still marked Experimental.

Closes-bug:1367307

Change-Id: I59adfcae589b9481efcf0bdb8c4d63e54ceb6a1b

commit_message:
Update for cinderclient 1.1.0

Also document v2 commands.

Closes-Bug: #1286664
Closes-Bug: #1369149
Closes-Bug: #1291139
Change-Id: Id21c03c8772b3db4a851e4af015d507a5e293f29
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/76/121376/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
The cinder client is the command-line interface (CLI) for the OpenStack Block Storage API and its extensions. This chapter documents cinder version 1.1.0. usage: cinder [--version] [--debug] [--os-auth-system <auth-system>] [--service-type <service-type>] [--service-name <service-name>] [--os-volume-api-version <volume-api-ver>] [--retries <retries>] [--os-auth-strategy <auth-strategy>] [--os-username <auth-user-name>] [--os-password <auth-password>] [--os-tenant-name <auth-tenant-name>] [--os-tenant-id <auth-tenant-id>] [--os-auth-url <auth-url>] [--os-user-id <auth-user-id>] [--os-user-domain-id <auth-user-domain-id>] [--os-user-domain-name <auth-user-domain-name>] [--os-project-id <auth-project-id>] [--os-project-name <auth-project-name>] [--os-project-domain-id <auth-project-domain-id>] [--os-project-domain-name <auth-project-domain-name>] [--os-cert <certificate>] [--os-key <key>] [--os-region-name <region-name>] [--os-token <token>] [--os-url <url>] [--os-cacert <ca-certificate>] Lists absolute limits for a user. Lists all availability zones. Creates a volume backup. Removes a backup. Lists all backups. Restores a backup. Show backup details. Creates a volume. Shows user credentials returned from auth. Removes one or more volumes. Creates encryption type for a volume type. Admin only. Deletes encryption type for a volume type. Admin only. Shows encryption type details for volume types. Admin only. Shows encryption type details for volume type. Admin only. Discovers endpoints registered by authentication service. Attempts to extend size of an existing volume. Lists current volume types and extra specs. Attempts force-delete of volume, regardless of state. Lists all volumes. Sets or deletes volume metadata. Shows volume metadata. Updates volume metadata. Migrates volume to a new host. Associates qos specs with specified volume type. Creates a qos specs. Deletes a specified qos specs. Disassociates qos specs from specified volume type. Disassociates qos specs from all associations. Gets all associations for specified qos specs. Sets or unsets specifications for a qos spec. Lists qos specs. Shows a specified qos specs. Lists quotas for a quota class. Updates quotas for a quota class. Lists default quotas for a tenant. Lists quotas for a tenant. Updates quotas for a tenant. Lists quota usage for a tenant. Lists rate limits for a user. Updates volume read-only access-mode flag. Renames a volume. Explicitly updates the volume state. Disables the service. Enables the service. Lists all services. Filter by host and service binary. set-bootable Update bootable status of a volume. Shows volume details. Creates a snapshot. Lists all snapshots. Sets or deletes snapshot metadata. Shows snapshot metadata. Updates snapshot metadata. Renames a snapshot. Explicitly updates the snapshot state. Shows snapshot details. Undoes a transfer. Lists all transfers. Show transfer details. Creates a volume type. Deletes a specified volume type. Sets or unsets extra_spec for a volume type. Lists available 'volume types'. Uploads volume to Image Service as an image. Prints arguments for bash_completion. Shows help about this program or one of its Lists all available os-api extensions. Shows debugging output. Service type. For most actions, default is volume. Service name. Default=env[CINDER_SERVICE_NAME]. Volume service name. Default=env[CINDER_VOLUME_SERVICE_NAME]. Endpoint type, which is publicURL or internalURL. Default=nova env[CINDER_ENDPOINT_TYPE] or publicURL. Block Storage API version. Valid values are 1 or 2. Default=env[OS_VOLUME_API_VERSION]. --retries <retries> Number of retries. --os-auth-strategy <auth-strategy> Authentication strategy (Env: OS_AUTH_STRATEGY, default keystone). For now, any other value will disable the authentication --os-username <auth-user-name> OpenStack user name. Default=env[OS_USERNAME]. --os-password <auth-password> Password for OpenStack user. Default=env[OS_PASSWORD]. --os-tenant-name <auth-tenant-name> Tenant name. Default=env[OS_TENANT_NAME]. --os-tenant-id <auth-tenant-id> ID for the tenant. Default=env[OS_TENANT_ID]. --os-auth-url <auth-url> URL for the authentication service. Default=env[OS_AUTH_URL]. --os-user-id <auth-user-id> Authentication user ID (Env: OS_USER_ID) --os-user-domain-id <auth-user-domain-id> OpenStack user domain ID. Defaults to env[OS_USER_DOMAIN_ID]. --os-user-domain-name <auth-user-domain-name> OpenStack user domain name. Defaults to env[OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME]. --os-project-id <auth-project-id> Another way to specify tenant ID. This option is mutually exclusive with --os-tenant-id. Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_ID]. --os-project-name <auth-project-name> Another way to specify tenant name. This option is mutually exclusive with --os-tenant-name. Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_NAME]. --os-project-domain-id <auth-project-domain-id> Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID]. --os-project-domain-name <auth-project-domain-name> Defaults to env[OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME]. --os-cert <certificate> Defaults to env[OS_CERT]. --os-key <key> Defaults to env[OS_KEY]. --os-region-name <region-name> Region name. Default=env[OS_REGION_NAME]. --os-token <token> Defaults to env[OS_TOKEN] --os-url <url> Defaults to env[OS_URL] cinder absolute-limitsLists absolute limits for a user. cinder availability-zone-listLists all availability zones. cinder backup-createCreates a volume backup. Name or ID of volume to back up. Backup container name. Default=None. Backup name. Default=None. Backup description. Default=None. cinder backup-deleteRemoves a backup. Name or ID of backup to delete. cinder backup-listLists all backups. cinder backup-restoreRestores a backup. ID of backup to restore. --volume-id <volume> ID or name of backup volume to which to restore. Default=None. cinder backup-showShow backup details. Name or ID of backup. cinder createCreates a volume. Volume size, in GBs. Creates volume from snapshot ID. Default=None. Creates volume from volume ID. Default=None. Creates volume from image ID. Default=None. Volume name. Default=None. Volume description. Default=None. Volume type. Default=None. Availability zone for volume. Default=None. Metadata key and value pairs. Default=None. cinder credentialsShows user credentials returned from auth. cinder deleteRemoves one or more volumes. Name or ID of volume to delete. Separate multiple volumes with a space. cinder encryption-type-createCreates encryption type for a volume type. Admin only. Name or ID of volume type. The class that provides encryption support. For example, a volume driver class path. The encryption algorithm and mode. For example, aes- xts-plain64. Default=None. Size of encryption key, in bits. For example, 128 or 256. Default=None. Notional service where encryption is performed. Valid values are "front-end" or "back-end." For example, front-end=Nova. Default is "front-end." cinder encryption-type-deleteDeletes encryption type for a volume type. Admin only. Name or ID of volume type. cinder encryption-type-listShows encryption type details for volume types. Admin only. cinder encryption-type-showShows encryption type details for volume type. Admin only. Name or ID of volume type. cinder endpointsDiscovers endpoints registered by authentication service. cinder extendAttempts to extend size of an existing volume. Name or ID of volume to extend. Size of volume, in GBs. cinder extra-specs-listLists current volume types and extra specs. cinder force-deleteAttempts force-delete of volume, regardless of state. Name or ID of volume to delete. Separate multiple volumes with a space. cinder listLists all volumes. Shows details for all tenants. Admin only. Filters list by a volume display name. Default=None. Filters list by a status. Default=None. Filters list by metadata key and value pair. Default=None. cinder list-extensionsLists all available os-api extensions. cinder metadataSets or deletes volume metadata. Name or ID of volume for which to update metadata. The action. Valid values are 'set' or 'unset.' The metadata key and pair to set or unset. For unset, specify only the key. Default=[]. cinder metadata-showShows volume metadata. ID of volume. cinder metadata-update-allUpdates volume metadata. ID of volume for which to update metadata. Metadata key and value pair or pairs to update. Default=[]. cinder migrateMigrates volume to a new host. ID of volume to migrate. Destination host. Enables or disables generic host-based force- migration, which bypasses driver optimizations. Default=False. cinder qos-associateAssociates qos specs with specified volume type. ID of QoS specifications. ID of volume type. cinder qos-createCreates a qos specs. Name of new QoS specifications. Specifications for QoS. cinder qos-deleteDeletes a specified qos specs. ID of QoS specifications. Enables or disables deletion of in-use QoS specifications. Default=False. cinder qos-disassociateDisassociates qos specs from specified volume type. ID of QoS specifications. ID of volume type. cinder qos-disassociate-allDisassociates qos specs from all associations. ID of QoS specifications. cinder qos-get-associationGets all associations for specified qos specs. ID of QoS specifications. cinder qos-keySets or unsets specifications for a qos spec. ID of QoS specifications. The action. Valid values are 'set' or 'unset.' Metadata key and value pair to set or unset. For unset, specify only the key. cinder qos-listLists qos specs. cinder qos-showShows a specified qos specs. ID of QoS specifications. cinder quota-class-showLists quotas for a quota class. Name of quota class for which to list quotas. cinder quota-class-updateUpdates quotas for a quota class. Name of quota class for which to set quotas. The new "volumes" quota value. Default=None. The new "snapshots" quota value. Default=None. The new "gigabytes" quota value. Default=None. Volume type. Default=None. cinder quota-defaultsLists default quotas for a tenant. ID of the tenant for which to list default quotas. cinder quota-delete cinder quota-showLists quotas for a tenant. ID of the tenant for which to list quotas. cinder quota-updateUpdates quotas for a tenant. ID of the tenant for which to set quotas. The new "volumes" quota value. Default=None. The new "snapshots" quota value. Default=None. The new "gigabytes" quota value. Default=None. Volume type. Default=None. cinder quota-usageLists quota usage for a tenant. ID of the tenant for which to list quota usage. cinder rate-limitsLists rate limits for a user. cinder readonly-mode-updateUpdates volume read-only access-mode flag. ID of volume to update. Enables or disables update of volume to read-only cinder renameRenames a volume. Name or ID of volume to rename. New display name for volume. Volume description. Default=None. cinder reset-stateExplicitly updates the volume state. Name or ID of volume to modify. Separate multiple volumes with a space. The state to assign to the volume. Valid values are "available," "error," "creating," "deleting," or "error_deleting." Default is "available." cinder service-disableDisables the service. Host name. cinder service-enableEnables the service. Host name. cinder service-listLists all services. Filter by host and service binary. Host name. Default=None. Service binary. Default=None.
cinder set-bootable usage: cinder set-bootable <volume> <True|true|False|false> Update bootable status of a volume. Positional arguments <volume> ID of the volume to update. <True|true|False|false> Flag to indicate whether volume is bootable. cinder showShows volume details. Volume name or ID. cinder snapshot-createCreates a snapshot. Name or ID of volume to snapshot. Allows or disallows snapshot of a volume when the volume is attached to an instance. If set to True, ignores the current status of the volume when attempting to snapshot it rather than forcing it to be available. Default=False. The snapshot name. Default=None. The snapshot description. Default=None. cinder snapshot-delete cinder snapshot-listLists all snapshots. Shows details for all tenants. Admin only. Filters list by a display name. Default=None. Filters list by a status. Default=None. Filters list by a volume ID. Default=None. cinder snapshot-metadataSets or deletes snapshot metadata. ID of snapshot for which to update metadata. The action. Valid values are 'set' or 'unset.' The metadata key and value pair to set or unset. For unset, specify only the key. cinder snapshot-metadata-showShows snapshot metadata. ID of snapshot. cinder snapshot-metadata-update-allUpdates snapshot metadata. ID of snapshot for which to update metadata. Metadata key and value pair or pairs to update. Default=[]. cinder snapshot-renameRenames a snapshot. Name or ID of snapshot. New display name for snapshot. Snapshot description. Default=None. cinder snapshot-reset-stateExplicitly updates the snapshot state. Name or ID of snapshot to modify. The state to assign to the snapshot. Valid values are "available," "error," "creating," "deleting," or "error_deleting." Default is "available." cinder snapshot-showShows snapshot details. Name or ID of snapshot. cinder transfer-accept ID of transfer to accept. Authentication key of transfer to accept. cinder transfer-create Name or ID of volume to transfer. Transfer name. Default=None. cinder transfer-deleteUndoes a transfer. Name or ID of transfer to delete. cinder transfer-listLists all transfers. cinder transfer-showShow transfer details. Name or ID of transfer to accept. cinder type-createCreates a volume type. Name for the volume type. cinder type-deleteDeletes a specified volume type. ID of volume type to delete. cinder type-keySets or unsets extra_spec for a volume type. Name or ID of volume type. The action. Valid values are 'set' or 'unset.' The extra specs key and value pair to set or unset. For unset, specify only the key. Default=None. cinder type-listLists available 'volume types'. cinder upload-to-imageUploads volume to Image Service as an image. Name or ID of volume to upload to an image. The new image name. Enables or disables upload of a volume that is attached to an instance. Default=False. Container format type. Default is bare. Disk format type. Default is raw.

commit_message:
Fix table display

The informaltables were not displayed correctly, they were just shown as
paragraphs. Use table instead.

Change-Id: Ib25a097699773088d0d13a5ef2f37079de547173
Closes-Bug: #1369099

commit_message:
Make resource tracker track NUMA usage

This patch makes the resource tracker actually track and update NUMA
usage from instance andd resize claims, and periodic resource updates.

Change-Id: Iea9d076cb37e530f442faefacd2a59b6b6225e92
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/06/113906/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sixfrom nova.virt import hardware self._update_usage_from_migration(context, instance_ref, image_meta, if image_meta is None: image_meta = utils.get_image_from_system_metadata( instance['system_metadata']) if instance_type['id'] == itype['id']: numa_topology = ( hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology.get_constraints( itype, image_meta)) usage = self._get_usage_dict( itype, numa_topology=numa_topology) self._update_usage(self.compute_node, usage, sign=-1) # Calculate the numa usage usage_numa_topology = usage.get('numa_topology') if usage_numa_topology: if isinstance(usage_numa_topology, six.string_types): usage_numa_topology = ( hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology.from_json( usage_numa_topology)) usage_numa_topology = [usage_numa_topology] resources_numa_topology = resources['numa_topology'] if resources_numa_topology is not None: resources_numa_topology = hardware.VirtNUMAHostTopology.from_json( resources_numa_topology) free = sign == -1 updated_numa_topology = ( hardware.VirtNUMAHostTopology.usage_from_instances( resources_numa_topology, usage_numa_topology, free=free)) if updated_numa_topology is not None: updated_numa_topology = updated_numa_topology.to_json() resources['numa_topology'] = updated_numa_topology def _update_usage_from_migration(self, context, instance, image_meta, resources, migration): 'new_', migration['new_instance_type_id'], extra_specs=True) 'old_', migration['old_instance_type_id'], extra_specs=True) migration['new_instance_type_id'], extra_specs=True) migration['old_instance_type_id'], extra_specs=True) if image_meta is None: image_meta = utils.get_image_from_system_metadata( instance['system_metadata']) numa_topology = ( hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology.get_constraints( itype, image_meta)) usage = self._get_usage_dict( itype, numa_topology=numa_topology) self._update_usage(resources, usage) self._update_usage_from_migration(context, instance, None, resources, migration) def _get_usage_dict(self, object_or_dict, **updates): """Make a usage dict _update methods expect. Accepts a dict or an Instance or Flavor object, and a set of updates. Converts the object to a dict and applies the updates. Currently only accepts 'numa_topology' in updates, all other keys are ignored. """ usage = {} if isinstance(object_or_dict, (objects.Flavor, objects.Instance)): usage = obj_base.obj_to_primitive(object_or_dict) else: usage.update(object_or_dict) for key in ('numa_topology',): if key in updates: usage[key] = updates[key] return usage
deleted_lines: self._update_usage_from_migration(context, instance_ref, if instance_type['id'] == itype['id']: self._update_usage(self.compute_node, itype, sign=-1) def _update_usage_from_migration(self, context, instance, resources, migration): 'new_', migration['new_instance_type_id']) 'old_', migration['old_instance_type_id']) migration['new_instance_type_id']) migration['old_instance_type_id']) self._update_usage(resources, itype) self._update_usage_from_migration(context, instance, resources, migration)

subject: Hook NUMA topology checking into claims
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-05 14:04:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c5bfee7b225b26c6f64273cdaf2d86ae0c6f48ea', 'message': 'Hook NUMA topology checking into claims

This patch adds the ability to test claims against NUMA topology exposed
by the host and instance. This is currently a no-op as no code in the
scheduler will actually attempt to set the limits against numa_topology.

This patch also changes the resource_tracker resize_claim method to
accept the image_metada of the instance as it is used (alongside flavor) to
calculate the new topology that will be exposed after the resize is
done.

The resource tracker will not do any actual usage tracking yet - this
will be done in a follow-up patch.

Change-Id: I07b690243d481c855c5e706f968cf224b336a1a0
Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement

'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2014-08-23 18:47:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2e4f1e29b234805c1ac17fe6eeacc47dfba39825', 'message': 'Hook NUMA topology checking into claims

This patch adds the ability to test claims against NUMA topology exposed
by the host and instance. This is currently a no-op as no code in the
scheduler will actually attempt to set the limits against numa_topology.
Since getting the NUMA topology of the instance may require an additional
db roundtrip, we try to avoid getting it unless absolutely necessary.

This patch also changes the resource_tracker resize_claim method to
accept the image_metada of the instance as it is used (alongside flavor)
to calculate the new topology that will be exposed after the resize is
done.

The resource tracker will not do any actual usage tracking yet - this
will be done in a follow-up patch.

Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
Change-Id: I07b690243d481c855c5e706f968cf224b336a1a0

This patch adds the ability to test claims against NUMA topology exposed
by the host and instance. This is currently a no-op as no code in the
scheduler will actually attempt to set the limits against numa_topology.
Since getting the NUMA topology of the instance may require an additional
db roundtrip, we try to avoid getting it unless absolutely necessary.

This patch also changes the resource_tracker resize_claim method to
accept the image_metada of the instance as it is used (alongside flavor)

done.

will be done in a follow-up patch.

commit_message:
Hook NUMA topology checking into claims

This patch adds the ability to test claims against NUMA topology exposed
by the host and instance. This is currently a no-op as no code in the
scheduler will actually attempt to set the limits against numa_topology.
Since getting the NUMA topology of the instance may require an additional
db roundtrip, we try to avoid getting it unless absolutely necessary.

This patch also changes the resource_tracker resize_claim method to
accept the image_metada of the instance as it is used (alongside flavor)
to calculate the new topology that will be exposed after the resize is
done.

The resource tracker will not do any actual usage tracking yet - this
will be done in a follow-up patch.

Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
Change-Id: I07b690243d481c855c5e706f968cf224b336a1a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/27/112027/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mock from nova.virt import hardware 'system_metadata': {}, 'numa_topology': None 'vcpus_used': 0, 'numa_topology': hardware.VirtNUMAHostTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCellUsage(1, [1, 2], 512), hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCellUsage(2, [3, 4], 512)] ).to_json() def test_numa_topology_no_limit(self): huge_instance = hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCell( 1, set([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]), 2048)]) self._claim(numa_topology=huge_instance.to_json()) def test_numa_topology_fails(self): huge_instance = hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCell( 1, set([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]), 2048)]) limit_topo = hardware.VirtNUMALimitTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCellLimit( 1, [1, 2], 512, cpu_limit=2, memory_limit=512), hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCellLimit( 1, [3, 4], 512, cpu_limit=2, memory_limit=512)]) self.assertRaises(exception.ComputeResourcesUnavailable, self._claim, limits={'numa_topology': limit_topo.to_json()}, numa_topology=huge_instance.to_json()) def test_numa_topology_passes(self): huge_instance = hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCell( 1, set([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]), 2048)]) limit_topo = hardware.VirtNUMALimitTopology( cells=[hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCellLimit( 1, [1, 2], 512, cpu_limit=5, memory_limit=4096), hardware.VirtNUMATopologyCellLimit( 1, [3, 4], 512, cpu_limit=5, memory_limit=4096)]) self._claim(limits={'numa_topology': limit_topo.to_json()}, numa_topology=huge_instance.to_json()) self.get_numa_constraint_patch = None def tearDown(self): super(ResizeClaimTestCase, self).tearDown() if self.get_numa_constraint_patch: self.get_numa_constraint_patch.stop() numa_constraint = kwargs.pop("numa_topology", None) if numa_constraint: numa_constraint = hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology.from_json( numa_constraint) self.get_numa_constraint_patch = mock.patch.object( hardware.VirtNUMAInstanceTopology, 'get_constraints', return_value=numa_constraint) self.get_numa_constraint_patch.start() return claims.ResizeClaim(self.instance, instance_type, {}, self.tracker, self.resources, overhead=overhead, limits=limits)
deleted_lines: 'system_metadata': {} 'vcpus_used': 0 return claims.ResizeClaim(self.instance, instance_type, self.tracker, self.resources, overhead=overhead, limits=limits)

subject: Stash numa-related flavor extra_spec items in system_metadata
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-04 17:48:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ce2066d991320b5cc6318de13526da7c1f8f0dbb', 'message': "Cache flavors in the resource tracker

Currently we would rely on getting the flavor information from the
instance system_metadata in the resource tracker allowing us to avoid
additional DB calls unless data is not available (for legacy reasons)
which we assume is a rare event. This however makes it impossible to use
flavor extra_specs in the resource tracker without adding them to the
instance system_metadata as well, which is proven to be a Bad Idea for
overall performance.

We deal with that in this patch by doing a single query for all the
Flavor objects our tracked instances relate to, and caching them on the
resource tracker object itself (purging the cache on every periodic
update). This will allow us to query the extra_specs when we will need
them (currently we add a flag for this but it's not used thus far). for
the cost of one additional DB query and a conductor roundtrip.

It is worth noting that flavor data stashed on the instance as system_metadata
can go stale once the flavor is changed in the DB, in which case it is
possible to get old flavor data, paired with new(er) extra_specs. This
does not seem like a big concern at the moment,

Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
Change-Id: I83ca863d521c579d8f1fe6168d7b1096af9f14f1

Flavor objects our tracked instances relate to, and caching them on the
resource tracker object itself (purging the cache on every periodic
update). This will allow us to query the extra_specs when we will need
them (currently we add a flag for this but it's not used thus far). for
the cost of one additional DB query and a conductor roundtrip.

It is worth noting that flavor data stashed on the instance as system_metadata
can go stale once the flavor is changed in the DB, in which case it is
possible to get old flavor data, paired with new(er) extra_specs. This
does not seem like a big concern at the moment,

Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
Change-Id: I83ca863d521c579d8f1fe6168d7b1096af9f14f1
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2014-08-15 09:15:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c9ec2e88c6ec8c28d9c17aa561e77c20fb55490c', 'message': "Cache flavors in the resource tracker

commit_message:
Stash numa-related flavor extra_spec items in system_metadata

This is a temporary measure to avoid having to add additional persistence
of extra_specs data simply to facilitate merging the NUMA patches. Only
the numa_cpus.* and numa_mem.* items are saved from extra_specs at
this time. The expectation is that this will quickly come out in kilo
when the rest of the flavor information stashed in system_metadata gets
removed and stored elsewhere.

Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
Change-Id: I83ca863d521c579d8f1fe6168d7b1096af9f14f1

subject: Process power state syncs asynchronously
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-29 15:27:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/bede9fa7e2cf1cec6a6b6ea9cd628354cf8f0b6c', 'message': 'Process power state syncs asynchronously

The instance locking introduced in
cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 keeps the power state sane
between stop and the periodic task power sync.  However, locking on
an instance in the periodic task thread can potentially lock
that thread for a long time.

Example:
1) User boots an instance.  The instance gets locked by uuid.
2) Driver spawn begins and the image starts downloading from glance.
3) During spawn, periodic tasks run.  Sync power states tries to grab
the same instance lock by uuid.
4) Periodic task thread hangs until the driver spawn completes in
another greenthread.

This scenario results in nova-compute appearing unresponsive for
a long time.

Change-Id: Idbc00ddfcb7a6816433863ed1686ad8f7477d99b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-08-29 19:46:50.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/compute/test_compute_xen.py', 'nova/tests/compute/eventlet_utils.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/tests/compute/test_compute.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/baabab45e0ae0e9e35872cae77eb04bdb5ee0545', 'message': 'Process power state syncs asynchronously

The instance locking introduced in
cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 keeps the power state sane
between stop and the periodic task power sync.  However, locking on
an instance in the periodic task thread can potentially lock
that thread for a long time.

Fix this condition by executing power syncs in a background GreenPool.
Limit the syncs to 1 at a time per instance.

Closes-Bug: 1363231

Change-Id: Idbc00ddfcb7a6816433863ed1686ad8f7477d99b
'}]
commit_message:
Process power state syncs asynchronously

The instance locking introduced in
cc5388bbe81aba635fb757e202d860aeed98f3e8 keeps the power state sane
between stop and the periodic task power sync.  However, locking on
an instance in the periodic task thread can potentially lock
that thread for a long time.

Fix this condition by executing power syncs in a background GreenPool.
Limit the syncs to 1 at a time per instance.

Closes-Bug: 1363231

Change-Id: Idbc00ddfcb7a6816433863ed1686ad8f7477d99b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/17/117817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._sync_power_pool = eventlet.GreenPool() self._syncs_in_progress = {} def _sync(db_instance): self._syncs_in_progress.pop(db_instance.uuid) for db_instance in db_instances: # process syncs asynchronously - don't want instance locking to # block entire periodic task thread uuid = db_instance.uuid if uuid in self._syncs_in_progress: LOG.debug(_('Sync already in progress for %s') % uuid) else: LOG.debug(_('Triggering sync for uuid %s') % uuid) self._syncs_in_progress[uuid] = True self._sync_power_pool.spawn_n(_sync, db_instance)
